NO SPOILER
STORY TIP





Here's a tip about how to go about the end game ( Learn from my mistake ).
When you come to the point where you start your "LAST MISSION" make sure you max your relationships first.
I did not do this, and it left a sour taste in my mouth not doing it at the RIGHT TIME.
You might find ending the game a bit easier this way, but i think its worth it.

snippet.textDisplay: I’d like to ask about foreign players’ opinions on the story of this game. Chinese players feel that the story relies too much on "deus ex machina" (mainly because they can’t understand why the plot ultimately revolves entirely around a single family, with the lives and deaths of the characters in the painting depending on the rise and fall of this family). As a result, the story has been mocked as a "family game." Additionally, many Chinese players struggle to understand why the characters in the painting don’t resist. On Chinese internet platforms, this game has even been labeled as the "spiritual successor of Vichy France," implying that in the French version of FF, the French still chose to surrender. That said, there are also many Chinese players who love this game.

snippet.textDisplay: "I felt like I wanted to bring all of [the characters] with me at all times, but you can only take three."  <-- EXACTLY!  I've played many games like this, but I've _never_ fallen so hard and so fast for literally every single character in the roster.  This game is an absolute masterpiece; I'm only about 12 hours in (no idea how long I have left to go) and I've _never_ been so shaken (in a good way) by a game in my life.  This could well become my favourite game _ever._  Y'all simply must play this game.

snippet.textDisplay:
The levels LOOK very nice, but the level design is trashy. Basic bitch levels that mostly are snake levels with a few tentacles to explore things. I am usually NOT bothered by invisible walls in games, as it's mostly kind of obvious where they are. Not in this game, this has one of the most atrocious hidden wall gallore I have ever seen. And because the game rewards exploring, I was literally FEELING as in bumping in to invisible walls all the time. In the Visages area there is at least one that literally is just right out in the open. The also refuse to let you jump into your death with forced hidden walls with some exceptions where you just respawn if you fall. Because they were too lazy to prevent trickjumps and what not in areas or the level design is just so bad that they made it easy not to go out of bounds or fall for the players with invis walls. 

I think people are blinded by the beauty that they do not see how basic and boring the levels actually are. They feel like a UE5 techdemo at times where someone designed a nice looking space and then carved some small areas into it where players can walk that suddenly end in the middle of the world created.

There is one of those atrocious hidden walls in the old Lumiere location where you can see and item, you would usually just be able to jump on it. BUT NOOOO, they put invisible walls around it, and you need to find the very special and developer intended way to get too it just because of stupid invis walls, at least make it something transparent, a hole where you can see the item but not fit though or something. Just lazy and bad level design.

Loved the game, but it shows its flaws pretty strongly lategame. Too much OP stuff and skills. Even with the recent Standhal nerf, I one shotted EVERY SINGLE Boss in my NG+ run where I do not even do a fully optimized version of a build I used for Simon. Like all the low HP things to proc even more damage are not even needed. I am at Visages, I already did the singing dancing lazy I think and I once shot her as well, then I stopped playing because it was just boring.

It was challanging on hard and I put 100 hours into the game and I feels the pacing was done badly. There is like 50% of the game to do after you finish the story. I am glad I did finish the story b4 exploring too much (red warning areas helped) so I had my challanges on hard and it was a great game, BUT its very flawed and does not feel very balanced later on at all. If you play blindly on hard like I did its a nice challange if you not find the most OP things even for longer but once you find a certain picto and find out about optimized builds its just Standhal Standhal Standhal everything - boring OP shit.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm still waiting for the characters to kinda click for me... personally i feel like the writing is extremely blase, yet intentionally vague as if to give some sort of mystery and the idea that the characters have no idea what they're getting into, which is fine but feels like it treads into this faux- philosophical jargon that just doesn't really resonate with me,"For those who come after" is just not a cool slogan for the expedition crew IMO. There's a moment after fighting the lamplighter where a big story moment happens and I just did not feel like the gravity of the situation was really captured, the emotion was just kinda off, and left me just kinda laughing at their attempt to make a serious moment out of it, but that could also definitely be because they keep character costumes in cutscenes and I cannot take it seriously with a character contemplating their own mortality while dressed as a baguette salesman. That being said I do like the humor, and the gameplay is super fun, I have no idea how to play turn based RPGs so I'm probably putting points in all the wrong stats, but it kinda just doesn't matter even on the highest difficulty as long as you are good with the parry mechanic. Defense and vitality useless stats, change my mind.

snippet.textDisplay: Regarding the criticism about parrying being over focussed as the defence mechanic - I think dodging is going to be just as well used for most players. Disregarding jump counters and gradient counters where they’re you’re only option, all other attacks give you the choice of a forgiving dodge to avoid the ridiculously high damage (on extreme) vs a difficult but rewarding parry. So when you’re learning attack patterns you should probably be dodging until you lock in the timing with perfect dodges, then you know you can hit those parries every time. Also for multi hit attacks, you have to parry each hit to actually get the counterattack. So if you fail one of the parries, you may as well start dodging the rest instead to have an easier time avoiding damage at least. There are also combos that end in a jump counters or gradient counter so you can’t get a parry counter attack anyway, may as well dodge the opening hits of those. Also the Dodger lumina is 1 point so you should have it up on every character

snippet.textDisplay: For me, it's a 7 out of 10 game. It doesn't do anything better that other games in recent years have. Doesn't have writing as good as BG3, or KDC2. It doesn't innovate traversal like TOTK. It's graphics are standard quality. It doesn't have interesting environments that are worth exploring just to see the sights, like Elden Ring or Elder Scrolls games. Your only incentivized to explore for items. It's battle system isn't much different than countless other turn based jrpg's. It lacks other gameplay elements to make the game more dynamic like crafting or puzzles or asynchronous online features or minigames. It's overly melodramatic and repetitive. But I still enjoy it. Especially because i'm playing it in VR which makes it more immersive. But GOTY contender? That's laying it on thick. KDC2 would be more deserving of it. Better writing, better visuals, more gameplay elements, much larger campaign, much more replayability with countless story paths.

snippet.textDisplay: So people who say “it’s not immersive” or “turn based no thanks that’s gross I get bored” are the same people who didn’t like Pokémon on the gameboy or a few other VERY popular games of turn based strategy? I feel very fortunate that I can enjoy this game as much as I can an Elden Ring, Marvel Rivals, Kotor , Dragon age, Oblivion, Darktide, GoW, RDR2, Witcher, Cyberpunk, Persona, FFx onward and you name it. It’s that childhood imagination coupled with the excellent storytelling/ characters/ very rewarding combat loop that makes this a masterpiece. Like I said it feels good being able to enjoy this game for what it is
snippet.textOriginal: So people who say “it’s not immersive” or “turn based no thanks that’s gross I get bored” are the same people who didn’t like Pokémon on the gameboy or a few other VERY popular games of turn based strategy? snippet.textDisplay:
The game looked promising at first, but the further my little brother played the game, the more I disliked it.
      The arts style is great and the music is good, but the gameplay was uncreative. You can see how the idea of taking no damage by dodging, parrying, jumping, or countering just completely killed strategic gameplay. For ppl that have been playing games for 3 decades, this was a snooze fest. Because of these mechanics, the devs had to enforce the need for timing as a way to increase the difficulty. Which again, left little to no room for creative/strategic gameplay. It ended up being extremely counterproductive.

snippet.textDisplay: This game is a masterpiece in every aspect; every single department has done a stellar job! The music is amazing, the design is fantastic, the story is stellar, even the direction of the cinematics feels better than Hollywood movies. Even if one does not like the "turn based combat", they should give this game a go. It is not simply a game, its an amazing story. You honestly get invested in the story, trying to figure out the story, feel anxious about what is going to happen next. And even though the story generally can be classified as "drama",  the subtle comedic reliefs that are sprinkled here and there are amazing! Truly a work of art!
snippet.textOriginal: This game is a masterpiece in every aspect; every single department has done a stellar job! You honestly get invested in the story, trying to figure out the story, feel anxious about what is going to happen next. snippet.textDisplay: This game is so brilliant, man. Makes you wonder why no one else seems to be capitalizing on this formula. Imagine an entire series of highly cinematic, story-focused, turn-based RPGs set in the highest of high-fantasy settings, but with the backing of a 5 billion dollar company - like Square Enix or something. It'd be a gold mine - an infinite money glitch, basically - one could literally exploit it forever unless you do something stupid like, say, force the franchise with the multi-million person fanbase to conform to a more competitive/abundant genre that they have no pedigree in. But only an idiot would do that!

snippet.textDisplay:
Peak fiction. This game is an absolute triumph in every sense. The visual fidelity is breathtaking, with some of the most impressive facial animations and hair physics I've ever seen. The art style is nothing short of stunning—imagine a watercolor painting that moves, full of life and depth. When it comes to turn-based combat, this is the best implementation I've encountered—strategically rich and allowing for countless character builds.

The voice acting and motion capture performances? Oscar-worthy. Every line is delivered with such authenticity and emotion. The score is equally mesmerizing—hauntingly beautiful compositions that elevate the cinematic presentation.

The writing and character development will grip you from the first scene, and the dialogue keeps you fully engaged throughout. The pacing is impeccable, both in terms of the story and gameplay. It introduces new layers of complexity and mechanics at the perfect moments, keeping things fresh long after most games have already shown you all they have to offer.

This is more than just a game—Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 represents a watershed moment in the gaming industry. It sets a new bar for what is possible, pushing boundaries in ways that will redefine the industry for generations to come.

In short, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is a masterpiece. A true work of art that redefines what games can achieve.

snippet.textDisplay:
Counter point on the dodge/parry:

I feel like what the game designers intended was for dodge to be used when you’re learning attack timings when seeing new enemies. Or when you just can’t nail the parry timing yet. 

Once you learn the timing, yeah, parry is always better. But it’s good to have an alternative with a more lax timing window to learn the timings.

I’d say the system is near perfect, personally.

snippet.textDisplay: IMO. I think Morden RPG missed the point with the Soul-Like and others that takes too much time to complete and enjoy. snippet.textDisplay: This game is amazing! I downloaded last night and played from 6am to 2:30pm . I put a full work day into this game on my first playthrough and with my serious adhd that says something about the story. It plays like a souls game mixed with a turn based final fantasy and the art is just gorgeous! It’s almost a perfect game. The only negative I can find in my first 8 hours is the slow progression through tutorials in the early game.. I didn’t know what to do with the lumina point things or the weapon upgrade things for a while after getting my first. This slow progression could also just be that I am exploring EVERYTHING though lol 4.8 stars out of 5
snippet.textOriginal: This game is amazing! I downloaded last night and played from 6am to 2:30pm . snippet.textDisplay:
Have you played Legend of Dragoon? It's the game that got me into RPGs, and while I know it's objectively not great, the timing based combat of Expedition 33 immediately reminded me of it and I've been waiting for the release ever since. Now that I've played a few hours, I can say that it doesn't really capture that same essence, but it doesn't matter. This game is amazing so far. 

Also, I'm really sorry for your loss. I've been dreading that day for years. As a son, it's an unfortunate reality that we all have to face one day. There's nothing I can say to make it any better; I know. But your community is always here to distract, uplift, and empathize with you. 

Thank you for all of the amazing guides and videos over the years. I'm sure you do, but I hope you realize how large of an impact you've had on so many people.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Something about this game really stood out to me ever since the initial reveal trailer. Usually I’m averse to any new “high-fidelity realistic graphics in a vaguely modern-fantasy setting” games, which this would seem to be—but it had a good feel to it from the start and I can’t quite explain why. Although I’m realizing that some of my favorite games have to do with characters grappling with/struggling against seemingly inevitable and impending death (Majora’s Mask and Xenoblade Chronicles 3 come to mind).
snippet.textOriginal: Something about this game really stood out to me ever since the initial reveal trailer. Usually I’m averse to any new “high-fidelity realistic graphics in a vaguely modern-fantasy setting” games, which this would seem to be—but it had a good feel to it from the start and I can’t quite explain why. Although I’m realizing that some of my favorite games have to do with characters grappling with/struggling against seemingly inevitable and impending death (Majora’s Mask and Xenoblade Chronicles 3 come to mind).

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry about your mom man. I lost mine to cancer about 6 or 7 years ago. The pain eventually dulls down, and the random grip of grief will eventually become less frequent. You will of course never forget, and you will always remember your mom, but hang in there. The first year for me was brutal. Year 2 was hard too, 3, 4, etc. started to get less and less painful. It's incredible how much magic a mom brings to a son.

snippet.textDisplay: I just can’t get into turn based combat. I’ve tried many times. I like constant tests of hand eye coordination and if a video game doesn’t excel at that exact thing, I lose interest very very quickly. I don’t feel good strategising or outsmarting a programmed  problem. Atleast with real time combat you are tangibly getting better/  faster reaction times. it puts me in the same state of mind as one would enter while playing an instrument, working out or playing a sport. Turn based games just don’t do that for me.

snippet.textDisplay: 1:07 In French, it's "clair-obscur", not "clair-obscure", which would mix both masculine and feminine adjectives (we don't do that). In English, we more commonly say "chiaroscuro", which is taken from the Italian. Let's hope they didn't go overboard with the UE5 features and that the game runs on normal PCs. EDIT: Apparently, they did. Same slow blurring as in Solasta II. Is there still a good graphics engine around or was UE4 the last of them?

snippet.textDisplay:
It is chiaroscuro and it is Italian in origin.  Anyone who has taken a basic art history course is bound to have been taught this. Once it is pointed out to you it becomes really clear why someone like Rembrandt is considered a master beyond many of his peers. Sandfall Interactive is a French developer which explains their language version, but it is clearly a ripoff of an extremely well known art term.

But I am definitely hyped to play it :)

snippet.textDisplay:
This game looks interesting, it looks like a painting and the story sounds interesting as well.  Might go for this one although I have a massive backlog to get through, still it looks and sounds quite intriguing.

Grief is painful when you lose those you love, my mum died over two and a half years ago suddenly from a build up of a pain killer she had been prescribed for nerve pain due to the arthritis she had in her legs for over a decade, she could barely walk in her last days.  I miss her every day.  There was a game I played before and after her death where the main character's grandmother died and she was talking about her grief, it hit quite hard.  
It hit even harder when a child abusing narcissist invoked the memory of my mum against me a few days before the second year mark since her death, I had to report the narcissist and their partner for their abuse of their child since the child's birth, like hitting the child hard enough to cause bleeding as well as neglect and using the child as a prop to lure in more victims, and their almost, technically, murder of me almost 11 months ago when the distress of their abuse of me broke me and left me in a very dark place that resulted in my ending up with a 10cm full thickness laceration of the midline forehead just as their doing their discard phase of me, they leeched a lot of money out of me while I investigated them when their partner forced an ultimatum on me - Don't call CPS on us or we'll never forgive you nor be friends.

Grief is never linear and it hits at any time no matter how long it's been since the loss happened.  Grieving is healthy and letting yourself grieve is better than bottling it all in until it all comes out at the worst possible time.

snippet.textDisplay:
I really appreciated the personal story here. I lost my mom a couple of years ago. I wasn't expecting how much it would impact me. I've been through a lot, have a thick skin. Grew up in a rough neighborhood (South Boston, during the late 70s and 80s). Lots of adversity. That is to say, I'm rarely rattled; I don't cry at sad movies; I'm not sentimental; I'm the last one to arrive and first one to leave at holiday dinners. I usually take the punches and move on. 

My mom's death, however, broke me. And like you, it manifests in the strangest ways, like hearing a Fleetwood Mac song while driving and just tearing up. Or passing by a classic car I knew she'd loved. Needless to say, it made me a bit more sentimental; I started arriving a bit earlier to those holiday visits; found myself a little softer and a little easier to rattle. I'd realized, in hindsight, how much the woman grounded me and gave me strength, security, and even if we didn't see one another for a while, she was always a phone call away. 

Sorry for your loss. It's a tough one to deal with, for sure.

Or passing by a classic car I knew she'd loved. Needless to say, it made me a bit more sentimental; I started arriving a bit earlier to those holiday visits; found myself a little softer and a little easier to rattle. I'd realized, in hindsight, how much the woman grounded me and gave me strength, security, and even if we didn't see one another for a while, she was always a phone call away. 

Sorry for your loss. It's a tough one to deal with, for sure.

snippet.textDisplay:
My condoleances for the loss of your mom. I also lost my own mom to cancer last december (on my birthday no less) and I've been trying to cope with it by distracting myself with video games to keep my mind from it. Hopefully the themes in this game don't tug on those strings too hard and I'll be able to handle them, since it still feels so recent and I still can't believe she is gone.

I knew that the first time I saw this game that it's going to be something special and I'm happy that, at least from the reviews, it looks like the developers manage to deliver it through and through. Even though I am excited to dive into Oblivion Remaster, I am going to put that aside and play Expedition 33 first because I really want to experience it for myself.

Thanks for the review!

snippet.textDisplay: I'm very sorry to hear about recently losing your mom to cancer. Same story here, and when you said that folks who have been through loss like that would understand this game, it was like a telepathic message straight to me. Guess I'm gonna need to check this one out. Thanks for everything you do; this channel is the best, most objective channel in the genre and sets the bar.
